column2: Chief Artists and Major Works
column3: Historical Events

column2: Cave painting, fertility goddesses, megalithic structures
column3: Lascaux Cave Painting, Woman of Willendorf, Stonehenge
column4: Ice Age ends (10,000 b.c.–8,000 b.c.); New Stone Age and first permanent settlements (8000 b.c.–2500 b.c.)

column2: Warrior art and narration in stone relief
column3: Standard of Ur, Gate of Ishtar, Stele of Hammurabi's Code
column4: Sumerians invent writing (3400 b.c.); Hammurabi writes his law code (1780 b.c.); Abraham founds monotheism

column2: Art with an afterlife focus: pyramids and tomb painting
column3: Imhotep, Step Pyramid, Great Pyramids, Bust of Nefertiti
column4: Narmer unites Upper/Lower Egypt (3100 b.c.); Rameses II battles the Hittites (1274 b.c.); Cleopatra dies (30 b.c.)

column2: Greek idealism: balance, perfect proportions; architectural orders(Doric, Ionic, Corinthian)
column3: Parthenon, Myron, Phidias, Polykleitos, Praxiteles
column4: Athens defeats Persia at Marathon (490 b.c.); Peloponnesian Wars (431 b.c.–404 b.c.); Alexander the Great's conquests (336 b.c.–323 b.c.)

column2: Roman realism: practical and down to earth; the arch
column3: Augustus of Primaporta, Colosseum, Trajan's Column, Pantheon
column4: Julius Caesar assassinated (44 b.c.); Augustus proclaimed Emperor (27 b.c.); Diocletian splits Empire (a.d. 292); Rome falls (a.d. 476)

column2: Serene, meditative art, and Arts of the Floating World
column3: Gu Kaizhi, Li Cheng, Guo Xi, Hokusai, Hiroshige
column4: Birth of Buddha (563 b.c.); Silk Road opens (1st century b.c.); Buddhism spreads to China (1st–2nd centuries a.d.) and Japan (5th century a.d.)

column2: Heavenly Byzantine mosaics; Islamic architecture and amazing maze-like design
column3: Hagia Sophia, Andrei Rublev, Mosque of Córdoba, the Alhambra
column4: Justinian partly restores Western Roman Empire (a.d. 533–a.d. 562); Iconoclasm Controversy (a.d. 726–a.d. 843); Birth of Islam (a.d. 610) and Muslim Conquests (a.d. 632–a.d. 732)

column2: Celtic art, Carolingian Renaissance, Romanesque, Gothic
column3: St. Sernin, Durham Cathedral, Notre Dame, Chartres, Cimabue, Duccio, Giotto
column4: Viking Raids (793–1066); Battle of Hastings (1066); Crusades I–IV (1095–1204); Black Death (1347–1351); Hundred Years' War (1337–1453)

column2: Rebirth of classical culture
column3: Ghiberti's Doors, Brunelleschi, Donatello, Botticelli, Leonardo, Michelangelo, Raphael
column4: Gutenberg invents movable type (1447); Turks conquer Constantinople (1453); Columbus lands in New World (1492); Martin Luther starts Reformation (1517)

column2: The Renaissance spreads north- ward to France, the Low Countries, Poland, Germany, and England
column3: Bellini, Giorgione, Titian, Dürer, Bruegel, Bosch, Jan van Eyck, Rogier van der Weyden
column4: Council of Trent and Counter-Reformation (1545–1563); Copernicus proves the Earth revolves around the Sun (1543

column2: Art that breaks the rules; artifice over nature
column3: Tintoretto, El Greco, Pontormo, Bronzino, Cellini
column4: Magellan circumnavigates the globe (1520–1522)

column2: Splendor and flourish for God; art as a weapon in the religious wars
column3: Reubens, Rembrandt, Caravaggio, Palace of Versailles
column4: Thirty Years' War between Catholics and Protestants (1618–1648)

column2: Art that recaptures Greco-Roman grace and grandeur
column3: David, Ingres, Greuze, Canova
column4: Enlightenment (18th century); Industrial Revolution (1760–1850)

column2: The triumph of imagination and individuality
column3: Caspar Friedrich, Gericault, Delacroix, Turner, Benjamin West
column4: American Revolution (1775–1783); French Revolution (1789–1799); Napoleon crowned emperor of France (1803)

column2: Celebrating working class and peasants; en plein air rustic painting
column3: Corot, Courbet, Daumier, Millet
column4: European democratic revolutions of 1848

column2: Capturing fleeting effects of natural light
column3: Monet, Manet, Renoir, Pissarro, Cassatt, Morisot, Degas
column4: Franco-Prussian War (1870–1871); Unification of Germany (1871)

column2: A soft revolt against Impressionism
column3: Van Gogh, Gauguin, Cézanne, Seurat
column4: Belle Époque (late-19th-century Golden Age); Japan defeats Russia (1905)

column2: Harsh colors and flat surfaces (Fauvism); emotion distorting form
column3: Matisse, Kirchner, Kandinsky, Marc
column4: Boxer Rebellion in China (1900); World War (1914–1918)

Art Periods/Movements: Cubism, Futurism, Supremativism, Constructivism, De Stijl (1905–1920)
column2: Pre– and Post–World War 1 art experiments: new forms to express modern life
column3: Picasso, Braque, Leger, Boccioni, Severini, Malevich
column4: Russian Revolution (1917); American women franchised (1920)

column2: Ridiculous art; painting dreamsand exploring the unconscious
column3: Duchamp, Dalí, Ernst, Magritte, de Chirico, Kahlo
column4: Disillusionment after World War I; The Great Depression (1929–1938); World War II (1939–1945) and Nazi horrors; atomic bombs dropped on Japan (1945)

column2: Post–World War II: pure abstraction and expression without form; popular art absorbs consumerism
column3: Gorky, Pollock, de Kooning, Rothko, Warhol, Lichtenstein
column4: Cold War and Vietnam War (U.S. enters 1965); U.S.S.R. suppresses Hungarian revolt (1956) Czechoslovakian revolt (1968)

column2: Art without a center and reworking and mixing past styles
column3: Gerhard Richter, Cindy Sherman, Anselm Kiefer, Frank Gehry, Zaha Hadid
column4: Nuclear freeze movement; Cold War fizzles; Communism collapses in Eastern Europe and U.S.S.R. (1989–1991)
